name: Uriel's Chasm
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 7 and up Processor: 2 gig dual core Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: Latest driver direct x 9 Sound Card: Latest driver direct x 9

reviews.review_text: Edited on 1/20/15 to add game mechanics detail (see paragraph four).   Uriel's Chasm isn't a game so much as it is an experience. Unfortunately, if you're not of the age group to recognize that, or if you don't know this before you press 'play,' you'll give it five minutes, declare it the most horrible game ever made, and move on.   I'm going to flirt with madness here and tell you it's [expletive deleted]  BRILLIANT . From the lack of a pause key or an options menu, to the midi-based music, to the absolutely brutal gameplay, to the lack of pyrotechnics, to the anticlimactic area 'wins,' to the interlaced, grainy FMV (that's 'full motion video' for those of you who weren't around  before  its existence)...all I can say is just...wow. For those who didn't experience computer gaming back in the early 1990s (just as CD-ROM drives were hitting the market), Uriel's Chasm very accurately replicates the  exact  experience of that era. Games were frequently nonsensical; they often changed screens abruptly, they didn't hold your hand, they didn't provide tutorials, and they most   certainly  didn't have giant arrows or yellow question marks to point you in the right direction.   As an actual game, once you get into it, Uriel's Chasm is challenging, unsettling and even a bit disturbing. Part of the purpose of this game (other than to take you back in time in a very real way) is to discover each new section and how to play on your own, so I won't spoil those moments for you here. What I  will  say, is that it very accurately represents what were three out of the four main styles of gameplay back in those days (the fourth being faux-3D shooters such as Catacombs 3D, Wolfenstein 3D, Doom, et al), but skewed through Uriel's Chasm's own twisted lens.  Game play is brutal and unforgiving, but that's kind of the point. The controls are extremely responsive, if not initially intuitive. It runs smoothly even on my three year-old big box computer, and there is a solid logic or pattern to each area (even the seemingly unbeatable final level).  I came to Uriel's Chasm as an active Presbyterian Elder, curious about the Biblical aspects of the game, but that quickly became a non-event, as the experience took over. Nevertheless, there is some usage of Christian iconography that may be disturbing to some players (such as spinning crucifixes that fire bullets). Play time is pretty short but, as this is more about the experience than the actual game, that doesn't bother me. With all sincerity, and without any sarcasm, I tell you this : Uriel's Chasm is art. Most people won't agree with me. Most people won't get it. Most people won't like it. I do. I do, and I absolutely recommend it to anyone who remembers what gaming was like back then and wants to relive the experience, those who are into hardcore gaming, or to those who are curious about it. All others should, as evidenced by the multitudes of negative reviews, pass it by.

(The description for this game flat out lies. There's no metaphysics here, and VERY little 'rich context' that in NO WAY can be investigated.)  I greatly enjoyed this game, but I would not reccomend it to most people. You have to have a very specific taste in these kinds of psychedelic games in order to appreciate it. Oh, and it takes 15-30 minutes to complete the game.   Uriel's Chasm is a very complex enigma. First off, I would like to say that there is no 'Shovelware Queens' as the description would have you beleive. I wanted to see their playthrough, so I googled it and searched for around 4 hours, and literally nothing even mentioning them popped up. This game is not based off an unliscened bible game, this is a game entirely handmade, not a revamp of a game from the 90's.   I would try to give this game a traditional review, but that is impossible. The appeal in Uriel's Chasm is not the gameplay. The appeal lies in something more abstract, perhaps the game's overall aethsetics. This game is more of a commentary on other things than a game in of it's self. This is a fancy way of saying, the gameplay basically sucks. The second level is a very well made side-scrolling bullet hell, but the first and third levels are tedious. Now, don't get me wrong, I greatly enjoyed each level, but not because of normal reasons. It is a lot like Sluggish Morss in how it is presented.   The enclusion of DMT is what made me buy this game, and what made me realize that this isn't a remake of a very old game. Why would someone trying to sell a christian game advertise DMT?  The best part about this game is the ending. I found the whole concept of this game to be extremely innovative, and I am excited to see more games like this.

here is this games story: your a girl who is in a space ship, who is against a giant mouth with wings that is called the garden of peace, and you need to sit still in space to collect faith, untill you have more than the garden of peace. you can destroy the astroids to collect more fuel (REALLY rare), ammo and bibles. what does the bible do? it changes the text at the bottom of your screen. what else does this do? nothing. after that, you are trown in a 2d space shooter where you are flying with a oil tank, where you need to dodge crosses that shoot round disco balls, blue men that are riding blue d***s, and so on. when you reach the end, you fight a xenomorph with the face of an old man, that summons a ball that has a cloak field around it self, and shoots a whole lot of fire balls and small disco balls. then you go on an acid trip to find jesus trees, seven times. when you have completed it, you will be sent into the garden of peace (i think) where you will fight the mega giraffe that shoot 1000 black and white balls at the same time, and you need to shoot it with a infinite amount of books. what happens after? go on youtube, i really dont know. 10/10 would use this to torture myself and my friends again. P.S. did i mention that this game is about religion?
Still better than Call of Duty...

A flawed masterpiece. One of the more original games I've played 2deep4me metaphors with allegories Cool graphics and nice aesthetic Great music Nice mix of genres  There are some nitpicks, like not being able to skip those cutscenes and the text that disappears fast My main gripe with the game is too short and easy so just wait for a sale when is below a buck

I liked this quite a lot. It has good retro graphics and is pretty much a brutally difficult top down shooter. It does have some odd themes and most of the difficulty is in the dodgy controls, though.
I survived the first level.

Althought i liked this game, i can not recommend it to everyone. This is obviously a parody to old bible games so if you don't get it you might end up hating it or not, what is to me i have only knew about bible games from watching AVGN's bible game reviews.  So as far as im concerned, this is way too much better than those old bible games, they were games/hacks made with the only purpose to make money, they just stack a few random bible passages and they put bible references in their name. Basically a scamm, this game is making fun of them.  What's is about the story, i think soo faar there should be 3 storylines. The people from the videos reviewing the game (in game) the story of the game with happens to be really bizarre and what is really going on, that to me it's just some drug trip hallucinations the main character is having since there are many references to DMT  The story is not over yet, since there is a sequel. also i think this game 'Selfie' might have something to do with this bizarre world  The only thing i didn't liked of Uriel's series is that they're too short games, but in the other hand i think the dev was more interested in the experience of playing this game than the game itself and it worked, at last for me...
I actually finished this game in about 35 minutes, I highly recommend it, it brought me closer to god. 10/10 would play it again.
Le sjws want to destroy our gaems

Seriously, it's not that difficult to figure out the game play for the first level. The other levels are several times harder than I generally have the patience for, and I'm not a huge fan of shooters, but the aesthetics and sense of humor were wonderful and kept me going to the end. Also, some seriously terrifying sounds toward the end. Perfect length of ~1 hr.

That game can make the time you spend playing it fun and pretty interesting. The game has a fine graphic and cool gameplay, the soundtrack is good. This was a unique experience playing that game and I liked it a lot.

Well.. what can I say, Uriel's Chasm, is just fantastic. It's like looking at the bottom of your mcdonalds bag and finding extra chips, it just tops all games by a mile, from the story to the art it just really pulls the player in. Apart from the 5 minute introduction every time you load the game, this game is a fast paced, space adventure. The introduction really pulls you into the game and makes you feel a part of it, a smart idea by the game devs to include actual humans talking to you so you don't feel lonely, becuase I mean, if you're buying this game, you're lonely. But all things said, this is the game of the year in my opinion and shouldn't be overlooked because it is 30p. I had great fun and would love to see another.
A must have game! really, buy this !! 10/10

There's a school of thought that says art should make people feel uncomfortable. I'm skeptical of the notion that games are art (I think Kojima was right when he said games are a service), but there's certainly unruly fodder for the argument here.  As noted in the copy, No-Wave scene musician/poet/whatever Jarboe does the in-game voice-over here. No-Wave music was notable for being deliberately abrasive, noisey and antagonistic, punk rock carried out to its logical extreme. Dare I say the music set out to be unlistenable. In the No-Wave documentary 'Kill Your Idols' one musician who was pivotal in the scene admits that he rarely listens to this sort of music and spends most of his time listening to generic pop. I bring this up because Uriel's Chasm is a sort of 'No-Wave Game' - it sets out to be un-fun, which gave me the strange feeling that the game was a joke on the part of the developer.  Most of the game is structured as some sort of shmup, be it the first stage's mash up of Asteroids and the first Thunder force, the second level's side-scroller, or the Director's Cut-additional final boss stage's Invaders clone. From a gameplay standpoint the problem is none of them are very fun. The first stage require's you to fill up your 'faith gage' by picking-up items dropped by destroyed asteroids, or just waiting, as the gauge slowly fills on its own. Guess which one I opted for? The second stage is the most playable, given the mercifully small hitbox your character has (hint: it's the cross on your sprite). The final stage is barely-playable given the headache inducing spray of bullets, which painfully flash white and black (I don't advise this game for anyone prone to seizures). It's worth mentioning that what I presume to be the end-boss (I gave up when my eyes ached and my head started throbbing) is scored to a track consisting of Jarboe's sampled grunts and screams over which plays her monotone free-verse poetry. It's easily the most unpleasant final boss I've ever had the mispleasure of playing, which wasn't aided by the ship's enormous hitbox.  That being said, the aesthetic angle of the game is interesting. The set-up is essentially that you're 'playing' a clumsy 'let's play' video (I realize that phrase is redundant), with non-'in-game' cutscenes consisting of the hosts commenting on the game, some of it being humourous, at least blackly-so. The game's certainly colourful, too, while the unlicensed head-trip bible game trappings keep things fresh. Light CRT and unlicensed-game-visual-glitchiness simulation is also a nice touch.  The real star of the game is its soundtrack. Simply put, it kicks ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. Be it the second stage's homage to the Megadrive or the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•in' shoegaze epilogue, the music at least keeps one part of this admittedly short game enjoyable.  It would be nice if it were possible to give this game a 'mid' rating, given it fits what one reviewer said of the film Demon Seed. To paraphrase, it's definitely not a classic, and it can't be said that it's even any fun, but in the end players with the right frame of mind won't have wasted their forty minutes. Just don't torture yourself with that end boss. Life's too short.

Holy hell, it's a hard game, the soundtrack it's good, a bit repetitive though, it's hard to control sometimes, you can't skip the between levels clips, they don't give you instructions for every level, but it's easy to know what you need to do once you do it, i actually like this game.

I have no idea what I am even playing. Is this even a game, or is it random madness? I assume there are multiple levels, but I can't even figure out what to do in the first level, which is a horrible asteroids type game where an anime girl (?) is ranting bible quotes at you. From reading some more the intent was to make a supposed old bad Bible game -- well, they succeeded absolutely.
It's a joke game and I get it, it's not making me laugh but I get it.

Uriel's Chasm  is a sad addition to the already-replete ranks of bad religious games; its intended satirical nature cannot save itself from its own dysfunctional gameplay, lazy execution and general misapplication of its religious themes.  It's maddeningly difficult to give a synopsis of this game, as the game never tells its own story properly. New players are introduced to one Sister Tabitha, who both monologues about being asleep for years yet inexplicably also knows about events that trouble the world. Players are then immediately dropped into a space setting, in a spaceship, with text explaining that they must collect Bible verses via mining asteroids. The game also launches a HUD that has four different values on it, including 'Faith' and 'Fuel', and before even processing what the controls are, the ship is crushed by some massive unknown object and the level is reset. This madness encapsulates the experience of  Uriel's Chasm  well.  This game is ravenously difficult, and little of it comes from fair, legitimate sources. The game's interface provides no indication for new players on how to play the game. Naturally, players will discover on their own that the arrow keys move the ship, but no other keys seem to do anything. Only after stumbling about on the keyboard will one find that the Z key fires the weapon. The shots fired from the weapon often phase through smaller asteroids, making it unreliable at best. The lack of collision sound effects for when the ship takes damage or when asteroids are destroyed makes it even easier for those not paying attention to spontaneously die. Perhaps the greatest injustice this game offers is that it has no pause menu, meaning that gamers that naively assume some level of competence by the developers and press 'Escape' during a level to pause will find themselves back at the beginning video sequence...which is unskippable. It's always unskippable. The unremovable Bible tracts that appear on the bottom of the screen during the first level in putrid green hues rounds out this spectrum of awefulness. The game's length is quite pathetically short at only four levels, though no player of sound mind will make it past the first. Perhaps it is merciful that this mess cannot last for long.  This game tries to save face by marketing itself as a satire of early religious videogames, with its lackluster interface and tough-as-nails difficulty serving as callbacks for nostalgia's sake. However, the protection that satire provides, despite being quite overarching, is not enough to save this title. What differentiates good game satire from  Uriel's Chasm  is that good game satire must convey that it has the potential to be good, but is intentionally made badly in attempt to pay homage to bad source material. Without the implementation of basic functions or a good system for the game to run on, the satire fails to parody its source and instead just becomes what it tries to mock. See  AVGN Adventures  and  DLC Quest  for examples of satire done right. The former parodied old-school platformers with brutal difficulty and the latter parodied modern microtransactions by making everything in-game DLC. However, both of these games have basic functionality and don't turn off players with awful aesthetics and unfair mechanics. If those two were designed the way  Uriel's Chasm  was made, then  AVGN  wouldn't have a jump button and  DLC Quest  would make players pay actual money for the fake in-game DLC. Because the developers do not understand how to effectively render satire in videogames, this game fails on all levels: as an actual game and, most importantly, as a parody.  Good games and religious games are not mutually exculsive in theory, but this game does nothing to prove this theory correct. Adequate functionality in controlling the character does little to forestall the mass of horrible elements that this game forces players to endure, from the lack of simple components like a pause menu to no explanations of backstory to such an out-of-place shoehorning of Biblical passages in a game that otherwise has nothing to do with Christianity, that this game can only be described as  unholy . Avoid this like the plague.  Uriel's Chasm  gets an F+.

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding cheese cake recipe you've come to the right place.  Ingredients:  1 cup digestive plain sweet biscuit crumbs 3 tablespoons sugar 3 tablespoons melted butter 40 ounces softened cream cheese 1 cup sugar 3 tablespoons flour 1 tablespoon vanilla 1 cup sour cream 4 eggs  Directions: For The base:. If you're using a dark pan, preheat the oven to 350. If you are using a shiny pan, 375. Combine the crumbs, melted butter and 3 tbsp sugar well and pat onto the bottom of a 9 inch springform pan. I also like to very very lightly butter the sides of the pan so that the cheesecake will not stick later on. Bake for 10 mins in your preheated oven and remove. Let it cool while you prepare your batter. For the batter:. Make sure everything is at room temperature. Combine sugar, cheese, flour and vanilla in a big bowl and mix on medium speed till well combined. Don't forget to scrape the bowl as you're doing this. Mix in the sour cream till its incorporated well. Then, add the eggs one by one, mixing well after each addition. Pour the batter into the springform and let it bake for 1 hour and 10 minutes After the baking time, turn off the oven and leave the door ajar. Let the cake cool in there for about 1 1/2 hours. Remove the cake and let it cool thoroughly. Refrigerate overnight. Release the sides of the springform. Eat.

Got this for free. Z to start, Z to shoot. Arrow keys to move the spaceship in the first level. The game is very hard and has very weird design decisions (huge and flashy subtitles, creepy voice reading the text, no options, FMV that is not skippable, etc). This is certainly one of the weirdest games ever made, with different gameplay for each level.  In the first level, you control a ship and the goal is to gather more Faith than the Garden. This is acomplished by shooting stuff and getting Bible pages, which show you texts from the Bible. After a while, if you just avoid being damaged, the Faith level keeps going up until you finished the level.  In the second level, you play a 2D scrolling shooter with very low HP and you need to get to the end of the level without checkpoints, killing Crosses that shoot, among other enemies.  I have not been able to finish the second level, and there is no saving system, so I'm not sure I'll feel like finish this weird and terrible game. Not recommended, two thumbs down!
I nominated this game for the 'Please Banish This From Steam' Award.

I've just recieved this game from a bundle among many others. I am a fan of Retro and Retro-themed games, I have been playing video games since 1979 or so . And I've even enjoyed some religious themed games (I can not be called religious and i am not a christian) on old consoles (from a company called wisdom tree). This is the worst game that i've ever came across. This is a pile of junk which is not worth the money or the time that you spend on it. If you really want to play a similar shooter game that is cool, fire up your amiga emulator and play 'blastar' from 'core design'. If you want to play a religious themed game play 'Spiritual Warfare' on NES. Stay away from this one. Avoid.

It's a weird game as you may have already found out by the many reviews for this game. However it doesn't pretend that its not. The makers were trying to be weird so you'll find a lot of reviews from people that were put off by that. Also there's Bible references immediately and throughout, but its definitely not in a preachy, shove it down your throat type of way. Why such negative reviews for that I don't know. Many mainstream movies and games refer to the Bible. Anyone remember Halo? Anyways I wouldn't buy it but that's my opinion. I'm writing this review when the game is posted at 49 cents... 90% off until april 6. I still don't think I'd buy it, but it does have trading cards so maybe. It's retailed on Steam at $5 so if you like weird games and its peaked your interest try it out, it's not horrendous. I've played worse, much worse.  The maker did this game on a budget I'm sure so the fact that its gotten the small publicity that it has isn't bad. Maybe being weird was a good idea...  Space theme 8 bit top down starfighter craft. You're looking for some missing space station. I really don't want to bore you or me with the details. There's pictures and video out there so see for yourself. Thanks for reading and have fun gamers.
